latin: In nova fert animus mūtātās dīcere fōrmās
english: My mind carries me to speak of forms changed into new bodies

latin: corpora; dī, coeptīs (nam vōs mūtāstis et illās)
english: O gods, inspire my beginnings (for you changed them too)

latin: adspīrāte meīs prīmāque ab orīgine mundī
english: and lead my continuous song from the first origin of the world

latin: ad mea perpetuum dēdūcite tempora carmen.
english: to my own times.

latin: Ante mare et terrās et quod tegit omnia caelum
english: Before the sea and the lands and the sky that covers all

latin: ūnus erat tōtō nātūrae vultus in orbe,
english: there was one face of nature in the whole world,

latin: quem dīxēre chaos: rudis indīgestaque mōlēs
english: which they called chaos: a raw and unorganized mass

latin: nec quicquam nisi pondus iners congestaque eōdem
english: nothing but inert weight and the discordant seeds of things not well joined together.

latin: nōn bene iūnctārum discordia sēmina rērum.
english: The discordant seeds of things not well joined together.

latin: nūllus adhūc mundō praebēbat lūmina Tītān,
english: No Titan yet provided light to the world,

latin: nec nova crēscendō reparābat cornua Phoebē,
english: nor did Phoebe renew her new horns by growing,

latin: nec circumfūsō pendēbat in āere tellūs
english: nor did the earth hang balanced in the surrounding air

latin: ponderibus lībrāta suīs, nec bracchia longō
english: balanced by its own weights, nor had Amphitrite extended her arms along the long margin of the lands;

latin: margine terrārum porrēxerat Amphītrītē;
english: nor had Amphitrite extended her arms along the long margin of the lands;

latin: utque āēr, tellūs illīc et pontus et aether.
english: Thus the earth was unstable, the sea unfit for swimming, the air lacking light:

latin: Sīc erat īnstabilis tellūs, innābilis unda,
english: Thus the earth was unstable, the sea unfit for swimming,

latin: lūcis egēns āēr: nūllī sua fōrma manēbat,
english: the air lacking light: no form retained its own shape,

latin: obstābatque aliīs aliud, quia corpore in ūnō
english: and one thing obstructed another, because in one body

latin: frīgida pugnābant calidīs, ūmentia siccīs,
english: cold things fought with hot, moist with dry,

latin: mollia cum dūrīs, sine pondere habentia pondus.
english: soft with hard, things with weight with those without weight.

latin: Hanc deus et melior lītem nātūra dirēmit.
english: This strife a god and better nature resolved.

latin: Nam caelō terrās et terrīs abscidit undās,
english: For he separated the lands from the sky and the waves from the lands,

latin: et liquidum spissō sēcrēvit ab āere caelum.
english: and he separated the clear sky from the dense air.

latin: Quae postquam ēvolvit caecōque exēmit acervō,
english: After he unfolded these things and removed them from the blind heap,

latin: dissociāta locīs concordī pāce ligāvit.
english: he bound them, separated by places, in harmonious peace.

latin: Ignea convexī vīs et sine pondere caelī
english: The fiery force of the convex sky and the weightless heaven

latin: ēmicuit summāque locum sibi fēcit in arce:
english: flashed forth and made a place for itself in the highest citadel:

latin: proximus est āēr illī levitāte locōque:
english: next to it is the air in lightness and place:

latin: dēnsior hīs tellūs, elementaque grandia trāxit
english: denser than these is the earth, and it drew the large elements

latin: et pressa est gravitāte suā: circumfluus ūmor
english: and was pressed by its own weight: the surrounding moisture

latin: ultima possēdit solidumque coercuit orbem.
english: occupied the outermost part and enclosed the solid globe.

latin: Sīc ubi dispositam quisquis fuit ille deōrum
english: Thus, when whoever of the gods it was had divided the mass

latin: congeriem secuit sectamque in membra redēgit,
english: and cut it into parts and reduced it to members,

latin: prīncipiō terram, nē nōn aequālis ab omnī
english: first he shaped the earth, so that it would not be unequal from any

latin: parte foret, magnī speciem glomerāvit in orbis.
english: part, into the form of a great globe.

latin: Tum freta diffūdit rapidīsque tumēscere ventīs
english: Then he spread out the seas and ordered them to swell with swift winds

latin: iussit et ambītae circumdare lītora terrae.
english: and to surround the shores of the encircled lands.

latin: Addidit et fontēs et stāgna inmēnsa lacūsque
english: He also added springs and immense pools and lakes

latin: flūminaque oblīquīs cīnxit dēclīvia rīpīs,
english: and he surrounded the sloping rivers with winding banks,

latin: quae, dīversa locīs, partim sorbentur ab ipsā,
english: which, diverse in places, are partly absorbed by the earth itself,

latin: in mare perveniunt partim campōque receptā
english: partly reach the sea and, received by the plain,

latin: līberiōris aquae prō rīpīs lītora pulsant.
english: beat the shores instead of banks with freer water.

latin: Iussit et extendī campōs, subsīdere vāllēs,
english: He ordered the plains to be extended, the valleys to sink,

latin: fronde tegī silvās, lapidōsōs surgere montēs.
english: the forests to be covered with foliage, the rocky mountains to rise.

latin: Utque duae dextrā caelum totidemque sinistrā
english: And as two zones cut the sky on the right and as many on the left,

latin: parte secant zōnae, quīnta est ārdentior illīs,
english: a fifth is hotter than these,

latin: sīc onus inclūsum numerō distīnxit eōdem
english: thus the god divided the enclosed mass by the same number

latin: cūra deī, totidemque plagae tellūre premuntur.
english: and as many zones are pressed upon the earth.

latin: Quārum quae mediā est, nōn est habitābilis aestū:
english: Of these, the one in the middle is not habitable due to heat:

latin: nix tegit alta duās: totidem inter utrumque locāvit
english: deep snow covers two: he placed as many between each

latin: temperiemque dedit mixtā cum frīgore flamma.
english: and gave them a temperate climate with a mixture of cold and heat.

latin: Inminet hīs āēr. Quī quantō est pondere terrae,
english: The air hangs over these. Which, as much as it is lighter than the earth,

latin: pondere aquae levior tantō est onerōsior ignī.
english: is heavier than water by that much, and more burdensome than fire.

latin: Illīc et nebulās, illīc cōnsistere nūbēs
english: There he ordered the clouds to gather, there the mists to settle

latin: iussit et hūmānās mōtūra tonitrua mentēs
english: and the thunders to move human minds

latin: et cum fulminibus facientēs fulgura ventōs.
english: and the winds that make lightning with thunderbolts.

latin: Hīs quoque nōn passim mundī fabricātor habendum
english: To these also the creator of the world did not allow the air to be held everywhere:

latin: āera permīsit: vix nunc obsistitur illīs,
english: now they are scarcely resisted,

latin: cum sua quisque regant dīversō flāmina tractū,
english: when each one rules its own winds in a different direction,

latin: quīn lanient mundum: tanta est discordia frātrum.
english: lest they tear the world apart: so great is the discord of brothers.
